items.title: Differential vegetation drought adaptability in global karst areas
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 16 October 2025

Differential vegetation drought adaptability in global karst areas
                    Yuanhuizi He1,2,3 na1, Li Wang1 na1, Jie Pei4 na1, Shidong Liu1 na1, Hui Yang5,6, Jianhua Cao5,6, Wang Li1, Zheng Niu1,2, Ni Huang1, Xiyan Xu7, Jianping Duan8, Biswajit Nath9, Shengping Ding10 & …Fang Chen11 Show authors

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 343 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeEcosystem ecology

AbstractKarst vegetation ecosystems are highly sensitive to climate change. However, relative to the other vegetation ecosystems, the adaptability of the vulnerable vegetation in the karst ecosystem to drought events remains unclear, especially in quantifying the contribution of different factors, including forest age, canopy height, terrain slope, precipitation, and human population. Here, we developed an evaluation framework based on a vegetation response intensity (RI), which includes drought stress windows and delayed vegetation response windows to detect vegetation adaptability to drought stress. Results show that the vegetation adaptability in global karst areas shows an increasing trend (-0.06 yr-1, p < 0.01), but shows significant differences. Although vegetation in all karst regions shows weak adaptability to short-term sudden droughts, vegetation adaptability in Europe (RI = 0.05) and North America (RI = 0.10) is significantly stronger than that in southwest China (RI = 0.23) for long-term drought. Notably, although the ecological restoration process can rapidly increase greenery in sensitive and fragile karst areas, the artificially restored vegetation with a lower age lacks adaptability to drought events in the short term. The adaptability of vegetation in karst areas to drought is mainly influenced by forest age (improved: 16.67%), slope (degraded: 18.87%), precipitation (degraded: 32.27%), and population (degraded: 31.22%) disturbance. Ecosystems with more complete ecological succession and longer duration exhibit strong adaptability to drought.

IntroductionContinued global warming has increased the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events1, profoundly impacting terrestrial ecosystems and carbon cycle2,3. Drought, the most prevalent extreme climate event worldwide4,5, poses a significant threat to fragile terrestrial ecosystems and can lead to permanent degradation of carbon sinks6. Karst ecosystems are disproportionately vulnerable to drought due to their shallow soil layers and rapid water infiltration, which limit plant-available water during dry spells7. Karst landscapes, characterized by their unique aboveground and underground hydrogeological features, are particularly vulnerable to these changes, especially under intense anthropogenic disturbances8. This unique hydrogeological context amplifies drought impacts compared to non-karst regions. Despite widespread observations of vegetation greening in global karst regions over the past three decades9,10,11,12 attributing to both climate change and ecological engineering efforts, the stability and adaptability of these ecosystems remain inadequately assessed. With growing evidence suggesting an increase in frequency and intensity of climate extremes5,13, understanding responses of vegetation to extreme droughts and assessing its stability and adaptability in karst areas becomes crucial. To enhance vegetation drought resistance in global karst regions, it is necessary to conduct research on the drought response characteristics and inherent driving laws of vegetation in karst areas.Karst regions, covering approximately 22 million km² globally and supporting about 20% of the world’s population14, are predominantly found in Europe, eastern North America, and southwest China. Ecological restoration projects15,16,17,18 in these areas have been recognized as effective natural climate solutions (NCS)19. Vegetation in karst areas is vital for carbon sequestration. The unique groundwater cycle system and water-carbon coupling processes enhance vegetation growth and chemical weathering of carbonate rock, which promotes CO2 absorption8. However, the challenges of water stress and ecological restoration in global karst areas are intricate and enduring, given the varied response mechanisms to droughts among different plant communities and diverse soil characteristics. The legacy effects of drought on vegetation growth and recovery6,20 in karst environments are still uncertain. Although previous studies have documented vegetation greening in karst regions, the mechanisms underlying drought adaptability—particularly the role of ecological succession stability and human disturbance—remain poorly quantified at a global scale.Quantifying responses of vegetation to climate stress and identifying effective NCS are essential scientific tasks for ecosystem restoration goals. It is necessary to focus on the stability and adaptability of karst vegetation ecosystems during extreme drought events. Ecosystems with high stability and adaptability typically exhibit lower response intensity (RI) and slower response speed to extreme drought7. However, the greening of vegetation and its adaptability to drought events may be different. A critical question remains: how is the adaptability of greening vegetation in karst ecosystems to extreme drought?21. Addressing this question is urgent considering the great potential22 and global priority of ecosystem restoration in karst areas23. Usually, drought has a significant impact on water stress. Drought leads to a decrease in leaf moisture content, closure of stomata, or leaf shedding in vegetation, thereby reducing photosynthetic efficiency4,24. This is manifested as an increase in red light reflectance with decrease in chlorophyll and a decrease in near-infrared reflectance, ultimately resulting in a decrease in normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) values4. For drought adaptability, drought-tolerant vegetation may maintain high NDVI during drought periods through physiological regulation, while sensitive vegetation may significantly reduce NDVI25. Therefore, long-term RI monitoring of vegetation NDVI to drought events can track the adaptability changes of vegetation.Leveraging the advancements in remote sensing, big data and cloud computing, we developed a method to detect vegetation adaptability under extreme drought stress based on all available Moderate-resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) remote sensing images and climate data from 2001 to 2019. This method employs two core indicators—RI and response lag—to gauge the stability and climate adaptability of vegetation. We define the window period of drought stress events occurring within one year as the Drought Stress Window (DSW). Similarly, compared to the window period of drought events, we define the time window period of delayed occurrence of vegetation response events as Delayed Vegetation Response Window (DVRW). Calculate RI by synergistically analyzing the changes in drought indicators within DSW and the changes in vegetation indicators within DVRW. To ensure robust results, three drought datasets drought datasets, including standardized precipitation evapotranspiration index (SPEI), famine early warning systems network land data assimilation system (FLDAS), and Palmer drought severity index (PDSI), were used to jointly assess vegetation adaptability in karst areas. Under the method, we first examined the spatiotemporal distribution of the vegetation index and drought index in global karst and their adjacent areas. While discovering a decreasing trend in the RI of vegetation to drought in karst regions worldwide, the RI differences in different karst regions were revealed. By revealing the effects of climate, human factors, and terrain on response differences, this provides a basis for differentiated management and targeted governance of fragile vegetation ecosystems in different karst regions. This study is beneficial for providing a scientific basis for vegetation protection and restoration in karst regions worldwide.ResultsVegetation changes in global karst regionsThe global vegetation in karst areas has shown an overall trend of greening. This greening trend is particularly pronounced in karst regions overlain by temperate forest, such as southwest China (slope = 0.0028∙y-1, p < 0.001) and the Mediterranean coast (slope=0.0024∙y-1, p < 0.001) (Fig. 1a, j). Vegetation in fragile arid karst areas, including the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (slope=0.0008∙y-1, p < 0.05), the Mongolian Plateau (slope=0.0018∙y-1, p < 0.005), and the arid western regions of the United States (slope = 0.0015∙y-1, p = 0.15), has also experienced a notable greening trend. Meanwhile, a significant increase (p < 0.1) in water deficit has been observed in global karst areas base on VPD, PDSI, and SPEI02 (Fig. 1k, m), despite discrepancies in drought datasets. Both the frequency and duration of various drought events, propelled by water deficit, have increased significantly (p < 0.1), corroborating the heightened drought risks in global karst regions.Fig. 1: Changes in vegetation index and drought index in global karst areas from 2001 to 2019.a The trend of vegetation index in karst areas; b is the R2 for the correlation between delayed NDVI and drought index; c The hysteresis between vegetation index and drought index, with pixel values of lag months in correlation; d, f, h show consistency between vegetation index and drought index in typical regions; e, g and i show hysteresis in typical regions; j Statistics on the NDVI changes in different karst areas; k Statistics on the frequency changes of drought occurrence with different datasets. Red and blue, respectively, represent the increasing and decreasing trend in frequency; m Statistics on changes in drought duration with different datasets. Red and blue, respectively, represent the extension and shortening of drought duration. Greater saturation indicating greater changes, and “*” indicates the significance of p < 0.1 in k and m.Full size imageIn the context of the observed trend of increased greenery and more frequent drought occurrences, regions where vegetation is highly water dependent are predominantly located in arid zones (Fig. 1b). Analyzing the hysteresis effect, we find that areas with the most rapid vegetation response to drought events are concentrated in arid regions, exhibiting a lag time of no more than one month (Fig. 1c). Notably, karst areas in the eastern United States and southwest China, despite being situated in humid environments, also demonstrate a pronounced reliance of vegetation on water, characterized by an average lag time of 1.2 to 1.5 months (Fig. 1d, e, h, i). This heightened water dependence is intricately linked to the prevalent water deficit conditions in karst areas.Response of vegetation in karst areas to droughtA positive RI value represents the vegetation’s response to drought events, with a larger value indicating a more intense response and poorer adaptability. Here, we have investigated the response characteristics of vegetation in global karst areas to drought (Fig. 2). Global ecosystems, particularly those disturbed by human activities such as southwest China, exhibit significant responses to drought (Fig. 2). Despite the notable greening of vegetation, the average response in southwest China is very high. Significant variations in vegetation adaptability to drought across different karst regions are evident, particularly when comparing Southwest China, Western Europe, and North America. There is a notable downward trend in the RI in regions such as southwest China, the Western Europe, and North America (Fig. 2b), which means that the adaptability of karst vegetation to drought events is increasing. The differences in these regions demonstrate the remarkable heterogeneity in vegetation adaptability to drought in karst landscapes.Fig. 2: Response characteristics of vegetation in karst areas to drought events.a The average RI of different drought thresholds; b RI trends worldwide; c, d, e The trend of RI in the eastern United States, the western European-Mediterranean and the southwest China, respectively.Full size imageTo better understand how karst vegetation responds to drought stress in the context of global water deficits and the observed ‘Earth greening’ phenomenon, we analyzed time series of annual average RI values of karst vegetation, revealing a significant (−0.06 yr-1, p < 0.01) decreasing trend (Fig. 3a). However, the average karst vegetation response in temperate (RI mean = 0.173) and global dry regions (RI mean = 0.143) karst regions is higher than the global average (RI mean = 0.079). The global RI is decreasing, but the decline is faster in karst regions, especially in temperate karst areas (Fig. S12). The vegetation RI declined the most (−0.0855 yr-1, p < 0.01) in the temperate zone, while the slowest in the dry regions (-0.0493 yr-1). Therefore, we specifically analyzed the four main karst agglomeration areas in temperate regions. It is worth noting that the decline rates of in Asian karst regions (southwest China: -0.106 yr-1) and in European karst regions (mediterranean: -0.109 yr-1 and western European: -0.08 yr-1) are both more than twice that of the global (-0.0493 yr-1). This decreasing trend in the RI suggests an overall improvement in the adaptability of temperate karst vegetation to drought events, and the improvement rate is twice as fast as the global average.Fig. 3: Responses of vegetation in karst areas to drought events.a Time series of RI in major climate regions. All represents global vegetation. Karst represents global karst regions. Dryland represents global dry regions; b Time series of RI among different karst areas in temperate regions.Full size imageDifferences in the adaptability of vegetation to drought in karst areasTo reveal the differences in vegetation adaptability to drought across various karst regions, we conducted an analysis of three typical karst regions: Southwest China in Asia, France in the Western European and Mediterranean region, and Missouri in the United States (Fig. 4a–c). Overall, as drought stress intensifies, ranging from a scale of 0 to 1, the resilience of vegetation correspondingly diminishes (Fig. 4d). The karst regions of southwest China (CK) exhibit the most significant response to drought stress (Fig. 4d–f). Notably, the response of karst vegetation in Southwest China (RI mean = 0.23) to drought is considerably higher than that in the karst areas of the Missouri (RI mean = 0.10) and France (RI mean = 0.05), across diverse time scales (Fig. 4e). The response level of vegetation in non-karst areas of southwest China (C) remains around 0.2, whereas it consistently exceeds this in the karst regions of Southwest China. In contrast, karst areas in Missouri and France exhibit lower response levels compared to their respective non-karst areas (Fig. 4e). This pattern suggests that the drought adaptability of vegetation in Southwest China’s karst regions is relatively weaker than in non-karst areas.Fig. 4: Vegetation response to droughts in different karst areas.a–c Three typical case areas: Southwest China, Missouri in the United States, and France; d, f The stability of RI differences with drought thresholds of 0 and 0.5 with different datasets; e RI heterogeneity at different time scales; g Heterogeneity of RI hysteresis at different time scales. The abbreviations in the legend are: Southwest China’s karst (CK) and non karst areas (C), Missouri’s karst (AK) and non karst areas (A), and France’s karst (FK) and non karst areas (F).Full size imageIn addition, with the extension of the drought index’s time scale, RI values across various regions generally exhibit a declining trend. Notably, the rate of this decline varies by region, following the sequence from lowest to highest: Southwest China, Missouri, and then France. Even when drought extends to a year-long scale, the response in Southwest China remains most severe, indicating a lack of adaptability to drought at various time scales. Conversely, vegetation response in Missouri demonstrates a decrease to below 0.1, reflecting robust adaptability to prolonged droughts. In France’s karst region, vegetation has fully adapted to long-term drought conditions. The lag time in Southwest China remains relatively stable, while in both Missouri and France, there is a sharp increase after four months, followed by stabilization (Fig. 4g). For short-term droughts (lasting less than 4 months), the lag time is the greatest in Southwest China, followed by Missouri and France. However, during prolonged droughts (lasting more than 4 months), the order reverses to France > Missouri > China. This variation highlights that China’s karst vegetation is highly sensitive and less adaptable to drought at different time scales, whereas vegetation in Missouri and France is more resilient, particularly against long-term drought conditions.Attribution of differences in vegetation drought responseIn examining the distinct responses and adaptability of vegetation to drought in different karst areas, we considered the influence of several factors, including forest age, canopy height, terrain slope, precipitation, and human population. Our findings reveal that there are significant disparities in the influencing factors across the studied regions (Fig. 5a–e). Notably, forests in southwest China are generally younger compared to those in Missouri and France, particularly in the karst regions (Fig. 5a). In addition, the forests in southwest China are situated in areas with steeper slopes and are encompassed by larger human populations. Further analysis indicates that forest age, canopy height, and terrain slope negatively impact the RI. Increasing forest age and canopy height can enhance adaptability. Specifically, the contributions of forest age, canopy height, and slope to adaptability are 16.67, 1.96, and 18.87%, respectively (Fig. 5h). Conversely, climate characteristics and human disturbance positively affect RI, implying a detrimental impact on adaptability. Specifically, precipitation and population density reduce vegetation adaptability by 31.27% and 31.22%, respectively. Overall, the primary influences on vegetation’s RI to drought in karst areas are forest age, slope, precipitation, and human disturbance, with their average contributions across scales being -16.67, 18.87, 32.27, and 31.22%, respectively. The relatively younger forests in southwest China, combined with significant impacts of precipitation and human activities, result in a lag in the ecological succession of its vegetation ecosystems compared to those in France and Missouri.Fig. 5: Attribution of differences in vegetation drought response in global karst areas.a average forest age distribution among the three typical regions; b–e Differences in forest canopy height, population, precipitation, and slope in the typical regions. f The impact of different factors on RI at pixel scale, where all selected pixels involve karst areas; g The contribution of different factors to the difference in RI index. The abbreviations in the legend are: Southwest China’s karst (CK) and non karst areas (C), Missouri’s karst (AK) and non karst areas (A), and France’s karst (FK) and non karst areas (F).Full size imageDiscussionWe assessed the vegetation response of diverse karst ecosystems to climate events on a global scale. This assessment aids in evaluating the adaptability to drought events and the ecological vulnerability of these fragile regions. We found that the RI decreases across different karst regions worldwide, albeit with varying spatial patterns and magnitudes. This aligns with other studies indicating a global trend of vegetation greening in karst regions9,10,11,12. Moreover, the escalation of global drought events underscores the need for continued attention to the adaptability of vegetation in karst areas5. However, our findings highlight significant regional differences in the RI during periods of rapid vegetation greening and increasing drought events. Global droughts have intensified vegetation responses in both dryland and humid regions, leading to hotspots of intensive response under water deficits. Despite a global trend of reduced response over the past two decades, possibly due to climate-induced and land cover change-induced ‘Earth greening’26,27, vegetation in dryland and karst regions still shows an intense response to perennial water imbalance.Our study also underscores the considerable impact of short-term drought on vegetation in humid and sub-humid regions. The adaptive mechanisms, such as the growth of karst plant roots and deep-water utilization in the vadose zone, are critical in these regions. While global greenness, enhanced by ecological engineering efforts and rising atmospheric CO2 levels, may offset some vegetation loss due to drought, the increasing prevalence of drought poses a significant threat to fragile karst vegetation15. In a broader context, the response levels of different karst regions are influenced by the global distribution of water and heat. However, exceptions exist, such as in the southwest subtropical monsoon humid region of China, characterized by its unique monsoon climate factors and carbonate rock coverage15,28. This region experiences frequent seasonal heatwaves and rapid negative feedback responses to water deficits8. Additionally, factors like shallow soil layers, limited water holding capacity, and substantial soil seepage and erosion, compounded by young, artificially planted forests, render the vegetation in global karst regions highly susceptible to extreme drought stress.It is noteworthy that ecosystems with higher forest age and canopy height exhibit stronger adaptability to drought29. As the vegetation restoration time in karst regions around the world increases, the RI of vegetation to drought events continues to decline. It is undeniable that the vegetation in many karst areas still has a high RI to drought. This implies the necessity of minimizing ecological disturbances rather than merely repairing them post-disturbance30. Contrary to some studies28 suggesting that artificial forests in southwest China have stronger drought resistance, our findings indicate that long-term stable forests (forest age>100) have higher drought adaptability compared to short-term artificially restored forests (forest age<50). This conclusion, however, does not negate previous findings but rather provides a broader perspective, considering our long-term time series study. The results highlight the need to truly reduce ecological disturbance, rather than repair it after disturbance. The natural vegetation ecosystem in karst areas needs to be protected, while disturbed vegetation needs to be repaired in a timely manner and maintained for a long time.Continued global warming has increased the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events1, profoundly impacting terrestrial ecosystems2,3. Our research has found that the phenomenon of vegetation greening does not necessarily equate to adaptation to climate change, particularly in response to drought disturbances. Drought, the most prevalent extreme climate event worldwide4,5, poses a significant threat to fragile terrestrial ecosystems6. In Asia, extensive ecological restoration projects have contributed to greening but have also led to incomplete and unstable ecosystem succession9,10,11,12. In contrast, the forest ecosystems that have been restored for over 100 years in North America and Europe demonstrate strong adaptability to drought disturbances. The adaptability of vegetation in karst areas to drought is predominantly influenced by forest age, precipitation, and human disturbance31,32. Compared to the lower population density in North America and Europe, the higher human activity in China exacerbates the vulnerability of the vegetation in karst areas to disturbance. By quantifying the contributions of forest age and anthropogenic factors to drought adaptability, this study provides actionable insights for prioritizing conservation efforts in vulnerable karst regions, such as protecting short-term artificial vegetation restoration in densely populated areas. With growing evidence suggesting an increase in frequency and intensity of climate extremes5, reducing the response of vegetation to extreme drought and enhancing its stability and adaptability in karst areas has become crucial. It is necessary to enhance the adaptability to drought events through the protection and sustainable management of aging forests. Therefore, reducing ecosystem disturbance and promoting sustainable ecosystem succession are crucial for enhancing drought adaptability in vulnerable ecosystems like those in karst landscapes.The main contribution of this work is the evaluation of differences in vegetation adaptability to drought events in karst areas worldwide, and the quantification of the contributing factors to these differences. Vegetation in karst areas worldwide is greening, while the frequency and duration of drought events are also increasing. Although vegetation adaptability in global karst areas shows an increasing trend, there are significant regional differences in the decreasing rate of RI, with the temperate karst regions exhibiting a drought adaptability improvement rate twice as fast as the global average. Compared to North America and Western Europe, the RI index of karst areas in southwestern China is higher than that of non-karst areas in all types of droughts. Although different regions have shown weak adaptability for short-term sudden drought events, the adaptability of southwest China is significantly weaker than that of Europe and North America for long-term drought. Our research demonstrates that the adaptability of vegetation in karst areas to drought is mainly influenced by forest age (improved: 16.67%), slope (degraded: 18.87%), precipitation (degraded: 32.27%), and population (degraded: 31.22%) disturbance. There is a large amount of ecological restoration vegetation in the karst areas of southwestern China, with an average tree age of around 40 years, much lower than that in the Americas and Europe. These conclusions indirectly indicate that karst ecosystems with more complete ecological succession and longer duration exhibit strong adaptability to drought. Therefore, we suggest that enhancing the adaptability of karst ecosystems to drought events requires truly reducing ecological disturbances, rather than restoring them after disturbances.While this study provides valuable insights into vegetation drought adaptability in global karst regions, several limitations should be noted. The reliance on MODIS NDVI data may not fully capture long-term vegetation dynamics or shorter-term physiological responses, as NDVI can saturate in dense canopies and is influenced by non-vegetation factors like soil background. The drought indices used, such as SPEI and PDSI, though widely accepted, incorporate uncertainties from spatial resolution constraints, potentially affecting localized accuracy. Meanwhile, the differences between different drought datasets can also pose difficulties in defining drought events and may bring uncertainty to the calculation of RI. Additionally, ecological restoration’s long-term impacts require further validation, as the 19-year timeframe may be insufficient to assess fully matured ecosystem resilience. Addressing these limitations could enhance future research through multi-sensor data fusion, higher-resolution climate models, and longer-term observational studies.MethodsMulti-scale meteorological drought indicesSPEI and PDSI33,34,35 based on the water balance equation are widely used to characterize surface dryness. The SPEI index has a multi-scale sequence ranging from 1–48 month since 1901, applicable to global land surface water availability analysis.The 0.5° × 0.5° SPEI v2.6 data36 used in this study is produced using CRU Ts4.03 monthly precipitation and potential evapotranspiration grid data based on FAO-56 Penman-Monteith Estimation. The PDSI is based on Thornthwaite-Mather water balance model from (1/24°) monthly Terra-Climate dataset37, which is calculated based on high-spatial resolution WorldClim meteorological grid data, as well as coarser-spatial resolution but time-varying CRU Ts4.0 and Japanese 55-year Reanalysis (JRA55). 1–12 month time-scale SPEIs from 2001 to 2019 were obtained in NetCDF format and converted to multi-band image in TIFF format for further process in Google Earth Engine. PDSI of the same period was available at the Earth Engine Data catalog.PDSI has been confirmed as a similar proxy to 9–19 month SPEI for qualified mid- and long timescale drought in China38, thus was selected as a comparison. Monthly multi-scale SPEIs and PDSI have positive values representing water surplus and negative values for water deficit, and were used to reflect seasonal drought and prolonged dry/wet conditions. The 0.5° SPEIs and 1/24° PDSI was aggregated to 1 × 1 km using nearest resampling method. \({SPEI}01\), \({SPEI}02\) and \({SPEI}03\) mainly describe short-term drought stress caused by seasonal water loss, such as decreased rainfall or enhanced evaporation in a certain month. \({SPEI}04\), \({SPEI}05\) and \({SPEI}06\) focus on the characterization of soil water conditions, such as soil drying due to reduced precipitation; \({SPEI}07\) to \({SPEI}09\) and \({PDSI}\) have the ability of medium and long-term drought monitoring38, focusing on describing hydrological drought stress, such as river runoff reduction and groundwater level reduction. In contrast, \({SPEI}10\), \({SPEI}11\) and \({SPEI}12\) with longer time scales are conducive to describing the persistent or periodic changes of the local long-term dry/wet climate conditions, such as abnormally dry or wet years caused by El Nino and La Nina.Atmospheric dryness indicatorVapor pressure (VP) represents the maximum water vapor content that the air can hold at a certain temperature, reflecting the potential water-holding capacity of the atmosphere. Water vapor theoretically increases with temperature, while actual moisture in the atmosphere may fail to reach the saturated content due to the insufficient water supply. Vapor pressure deficit (VPD), the difference between the saturated and the actual VP, plays an important role in regulating vegetation physiological processes such as transpiration and photosynthesis. High VPD leads to a decrease in stomatal conductance and limits plant photosynthesis, thus becoming an important proxy reflecting the ecosystem evapotranspiration process, water use efficiency and vegetation carbon cycle. It is an effective index to identify atmospheric water balance and global drought stress39,40. VPD, like PDSI, can be obtained from the Terra-Climate weather grid dataset37.Soil moisture dataSoil Moisture (SM) is the main source of water for vegetation growth. Soil water deficit is caused by changes in the ground water balance due to reduction in precipitation supply and increase in soil evaporation. The SM data products at the global scale have high consistency in the spatial pattern and trend of drought monitoring41. Here, we adopt three SM data in the research period. ERA5-land is a reanalysis dataset based on weather-driven data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), released by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) Climate Date Store (CDS). It provides consistent monthly/hourly global land variables for decades with 0.1° × 0.1° resolution, which can accurately describe past and current climate conditions.SM data comes from the volume water content of four layers of soil provided by the Surface Model in ECMWF Integrated Forecasting System, which are layer1: 0 ~ 7 cm, layer2: 7 ~ 28 cm, layer3: 28 ~ 100 cm, layer4: 100 ~ 289 cm, respectively. Terra-Climate also provides SM products with 1/24° resolution over a long time series. In addition, FLDAS also provides SM percentage data, coming from the surface parameters simulated by Noah 3.6.1 model in Land Data Assimilation System (LDS) of Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET). This set of data improves the meteorological driving data based on Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS), and provides a global monthly 0.1° × 0.1° SM images, including 0 ~ 10 cm, 10 ~ 40 cm, 40 ~ 100 cm and 100 ~ 200 cm underground SM data. It is available in the Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SeDAC) of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and provides continuous description and assessment of drought events42.Satellite observation and auxiliary grid dataMODIS-based \({\rm{NDVI}}\) of the 16-day return cycle (MOD13A2.006) from 2001 to 2019 was selected as proxy of global vegetation growth. Land surface temperature (LST) product of 8-day was provided by MOD11A2.006 at 1 km resolution. Global MODIS Land Cover dataset at 500 m resolution for yearly intervals between 2001 and 2019 were used to aggregate land cover types percentages, based on Annual International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP) classification. The fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) was acquired based on MOD15A2H V6 8-day composite dataset at 500 m resolution.Global monthly precipitation during 2001 to 2019 was based on fifth-generation ECMWF atmospheric reanalysis (ERA5) dataset. Terrain slope was calculated by the Global Multi-resolution Terrain Elevation Data 2010 (GMTED2010) dataset at 7.5 arc-seconds resolution provided by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA). The distribution of human population for the years 2020 was based on the global Gridded Population of World Version 4 (GPWv4), Revision 11 models on 30 arc-second (approximately 1 km) grid cells. GLAS (Geoscience Laser Altimeter System) provides the 500 m global forest canopy height information of broad-leaved forest, coniferous forest and mixed forest in 2008, available at National Earth System Science Data Center, National Science and Technology Infrastructure of China.Forest age distributions of four plant functional types (PFT) representing the 2000–2010 era, was aggregated using global forest age dataset (GFAD) on a 0.5° × 0.5° grid. The four PFTs contain Needleleaf Evergreen Forest (NEF), Needleleaf Deciduous Forest (NDF), Broadleaf Evergreen Forest (BEF) and Broadleaf Deciduous Forest (BDF). All these raster data have been re-projected into EPSG: 4326 with a resolution of 1 km for consistent analysis. World dryland areas are derived from the Aridity Index (AI) and come from the boundary of the dryland system that defines the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MA), in accordance with the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) definition of Drylands43. The regions included in this data set include ultra-arid, arid, semi-arid, and semi-humid dry types43.Global carbonate rock data and karst ecotypesThe global karst distribution data comes from World Map of Carbonate Rock Outcrops v3.0. This v3.0 revision provides a detailed and upper limit area of exposed karst terrain, which contains carbonate rocks that are susceptible to karstification with abundant but discontinuous or impure traits. Global present-day maps of the Köppen-Geiger climate classification44 at 1 km resolution were used in zoning under current climate change. It divides the world into five major climate zones (tropical, dry zone, temperate zone, cold zone, and polar zone), considering annual and monthly temperature and rainfall season changes, as well as referenceable vegetation distribution. Global Maps of Potential Natural Vegetation (PNV) at 1 km resolution were used to indicate vegetation cover in equilibrium with climate, which includes main types of biome communities, such as forests, shrubs, grasslands, and tundra45. We divide the global karst distribution area into 18 typical karst zones based on the global biological community data and climate distribution types, to distinguish the ecological characteristics and comparatively analysis. Each karst ecotypes maintains the integrity of the geographical distribution and corresponds to the climatic conditions and vegetation types that are as homogeneous in-class and differentiated between-class as possible. As a comparison, the buffer zone within 50 km around the karst area is considered as a non-karst area.RI calculation flowchartThe calculation process of RI starts from inputting the monthly NDVI and drought index. Firstly, to synergistically analyze drought and vegetation indices, we normalized the vegetation index and drought index using standard deviation, and constructed drought anomaly indices (\({{SA}}_{{DAI}}\)) and NDVI anomaly (\({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\)) based on standard deviation. These anomaly index indicate the situation where the current state deviates from the long-term same period level. Based on this anomaly index, we further defined DSW under different drought thresholds. For each pixel-wise DSW, we accordingly delineated a corresponding Vegetation Response Window (VRW) in \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) sequence based on the same onset and duration of DSW. On account of lag-time effect, the DVRW is obtained by delaying this window to the corresponding lag month. Here, we use a monthly delay method to calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient between vegetation index and drought index within DSW to determine the actual delay response time, present the delay months when the maximum correlation coefficient is reached. Finally, the ratio of the pixel mean value in the DSW to the pixel mean value in the DVRW over a period of time was calculated to indicates the response degree of vegetation to drought stress46 (Fig. 6).Fig. 6RI Calculation Flowchart.Full size imageTime series composition and normalizationNDVI were de-clouded according to the quality assessment band to mask could-contaminated pixel areas. Pixel-wise composition method provided by Google Earth Engine (GEE) Code Editor was used to obtain statistical characteristics of images and construct continuous sequence. Composited time-series images included monthly and annual \({NDVI}\) sequence composited by Maximum Value Composites (MVC). Impact of vegetation seasonality and climate climatic heterogeneity was removed using z-score based \({NDVI}\) anomaly and meteorological drought index anomaly. We calculated \({NDVI}\) anomaly (Eq. (1)).$${{SA}}_{{NDVI}}=\frac{{{NDVI}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}}{\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)}$$
                    (1)
                Here, \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) represent \({NDVI}\) anomaly of month \(i\), \({{NDVI}}_{i}\) represent the pixel value of current month \(i\), \(\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}\) and \(\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)\) represent the average and the standard deviation of \({NDVI}\) on month \(i\) over 2001 to 2019, respectively.All of drought anomaly indices (DAI) were normalized by the similar formula, including SPEI, FLDAS, and PDSI (Eq. (2)).$${{SA}}_{{DAI}}=\frac{{{DAI}}_{i}-\overline{DA{I}_{i}}}{\sigma \left({DAI}\right)}$$
                    (2)
                The anomaly indices denote the deviation of the current state from the long-term situation of the same month. \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) signify the magnitude of \(\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)\) that \({{NDVI}}_{i}\) deviates from \(\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}\). Specifically, positive value of \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) indicates that vegetation grows better than that of the same period; negative value of \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) indicate vegetation degradation under the environmental stress; positive value of \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}\) represents water surplus, while negative value of \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}\) represents water deficit. Tendency of NDVI was computed by Sen’s slope estimator47.Drought Stress WindowTo measure the effects of intensities of drought on vegetation, we used the negative deviation value of \({\overline{SPEI03}}_{i}\) from its annual level to represent different DSW (Supplementary Fig. 11). We consider \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < 0\) as drought starts. The \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < -0.5\) was recognized as moderate drought indicating that current \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) is 1/2 times \(\sigma \left({SPEI}03\right)\) below the value of \(\overline{SPEI03_i}\). The \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < -1\) denoted severe drought where \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) is one \(\sigma \left({SPEI}03\right)\) lower than the average level of month \(i\) in other years. The thresholds were chosen to ensure that widespread global drought events can be well captured. Drought events occur continuously over time and space, so we defined negative \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) detected for 3 consecutive months as one DSW occurrence based on monthly data. Consecutive identification and division of negative month allows us to find out the DSWs for each year or over the whole time period, and calculated its traits of multi-scale drought occurrence. The same approach is applicable to other drought indices.Delayed vegetation response windowsDue to global hydrothermal variability and terrestrial ecosystem heterogeneity, the response of vegetation to climate has latitudinal and local time-lag effects in spatial pattern, which reflects the important interaction of vegetation growth and climate change controlled by micro-physiological adjustment and macro-pattern distribution48. Taking into account the time lag effect is of great importance for prediction and assessment of vegetation dynamics under global climate change48. Pearson correlation was calculated between \({{NDVI}}_{d}\) and \({SPEI}03\) (Eq. (3)).$${r}_{{{NDVI}}_{d},{SPEI}03}=\frac{{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}\left({{{NDVI}}_{d}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\right)\left({{SPEI}03}_{i}-\overline{SPEI03}\right)}{\sqrt{{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\left({{{NDVI}}_{d}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\right)}^{2}{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\left({{SPEI}03}_{i}-\overline{SPEI03}\right)}^{2}}}$$
                    (3)
                here \({{NDVI}}_{d}\) represents \({NDVI}\) with \(d\) month delayed; \(\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\) means the mean value among all \(i\) months in the time period. The \(d\) varies from 0 to 6 months and the pixel-wise lag month was marked as \(d\) with the highest determination coefficient (\({{r}_{{{NDVI}}_{d},{SPEIs}}}^{2}\)). The same calculation process was applied to other drought indices, to figure out lag time between vegetation and drought climate.Vegetation response to drought stressFor each pixel-wise DSW, we accordingly delineated a corresponding Vegetation Response Window (VRW) in \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) sequence based on the same onset and duration of DSW. On account of lag-time effect, the DVRW is obtained by delaying this window to the corresponding lag month. Therefore, the ratio of the pixel mean value in the DSW to the pixel mean value in the DVRW over a period of time was calculated to indicates the response degree of vegetation to drought stress46 (Eq. (4)). The RI index calculated based on different drought datasets has high consistency, indicating that this method has high reliability (Fig. S13).$${{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}}=\frac{{\rm{mean}}({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}{\rm{in\; D}}{\rm{VR}}{\rm{Ws}})}{{\rm{mean}}\left({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}{\rm{in\; DSW}}{\rm{s}}\right)}$$
                    (4)
                Here \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}}\) denotes the vegetation Response Index under drought stress, \(\Delta\) refers to drought intensity and \({\rm{T}}\) means a specific period. Since the denominator is always determined negative, \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}} > 0\) indicates that vegetation is significantly impaired under drought stress, and \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}} < 0\) illustrates that vegetation remains stable or grows better when drought occurs. The same quantitative process was calculated for all drought indices for a comprehensive analysis.Calculation of the contribution of different factorsPartial regression coefficients indicated the sensitivity of RI to different factors. This method has been widely used in detecting different factors, which can effectively derive the effect of a single factor by removing the collinearity impacts of other controlling factors. Based on SPSS 22.0, we calculated the sensitivity coefficients of impact factors at different scales from pixel scales.$${RI}=\Delta +\mathop{\sum }\limits_{i=1}^{6}{S}_{i}\times {F}_{i}$$
                    (5)
                where \({F}_{i}\) represents different factors, with \({F}_{1}\)-\({F}_{6}\) representing forest age, forest canopy height, precipitation, population, DEM, and slope, respectively. \({S}_{i}\) represents the sensitivity coefficient of RI to different factors. \(\triangle\) is the intercept of the multiple linear regression model.Finally, we estimated the influences of different factors on RI trends by multiplying the sensitivities with RI trends. The influences of forest age, forest canopy height, precipitation, population, and slope on RI are represented by \({T}_{a}\), \({T}_{h}\), \({T}_{{Pre}}\), \({T}_{{Pou}}\), and \({T}_{{slop}}\) respectively. The DEM factor is automatically removed by the model when calculating partial correlation parameters in SPSS 22.0. Therefore, the DEM indicator is not included in subsequent calculations. The sum of all effects of different factors on RI difference indicated by \({T}_{{all}}\). The percentage (%) of relative contribution of different factors (\({{\rm{RC}}}_{{\rm{i}}}\)) was calculated as follows:$${T}_{i}={S}_{i}\left(\max \left({F}_{i}\right)-\min \left({F}_{i}\right)\right)$$
                    (6)
                $${T}_{{all}}=\mathop{\sum }\limits_{i=1}^{5}\left|{T}_{i}\right|\,$$
                    (7)
                $${{\rm{RC}}}_{{\rm{i}}}\left( \% \right)=\frac{{T}_{i}}{{T}_{{all}}}\times 100 \%$$
                    (8)
                Here, \({T}_{1}\)-\({T}_{5}\) representing \({T}_{a}\), \({T}_{h}\), \({T}_{{Pre}}\), \({T}_{{Pou}}\), and \({T}_{{slop}}\) respectively. Plus or minus sign of contribution indicate that the factor enhances or alleviates RI, and also indicates that the factor is unfavorable or beneficial for karst vegetation to adapt to drought events. The total value of the absolute contribution (%) was 100%.

items.title: Un Parco Nazionale per le isole Egadi e il litorale trapanese
items.description:
Secondo il WWF l'istituzione di un Parco Nazionale sarebbe anche un’opportunità anche per le attività economiche. 
The post Un Parco Nazionale per le
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Il WWF ha illustrato oggi a Trapani la sua proposta In una conferenza a Trapani presso il Museo Regionale Agostino Piepoli il WWF Italia ha illustrato la propria proposta per il Parco Nazionale delle Isole Egadi e del Litorale Trapanese presentando anche un’ipotesi indicativa di perimetrazione. In WWF ritiene che serva un approccio realista e concreto e quindi, superando ipotesi non previste dalla norma (come quella di un parco limitato alle sole Isole Egadi) o soluzioni talmente estese da risultare difficilmente praticabili anche sul piano tecnico, la proposta è quella di considerare oltre le Egadi la cosiddetta “costa del sale”, cioè il litorale prospicente le isole usando l’area marina protetta delle Egadi come cerniera. In concreto si tratta di un “ammagliamento” delle aree con vincoli naturalistici già esistenti: le aree di Rete Natura 2000 sia a terra che a mare (cioè Siti d’Interesse Comunitario e Zone di Protezione speciale in parte sovrapposte tra di loro), le riserve naturali regionali delle Saline di Trapani e dello Stagnone di Marsala, l’area marina protetta delle Isole Egadi. Proposta elaborata dal Centro Studi WWF Il WWF sottolinea che si tratta di una perimetrazione indicativa per indicare una strada possibile, una proposta che ha tenuto però conto di varie problematiche che hanno portato ad escludere dal perimetro dei Parco i porti di Trapani e Marsala, l’aeroporto di Birgi, i principali nuclei abitati di Favignana, Marettimo e Levanzo, le aree urbane di Trapani e Marsala.La presentazione della proposta, elaborata dal Centro Studi WWF con la collaborazione tecnica della Società TEMI srl, è stata corredata da varie cartografie. Partendo dalla sovrapposizione delle aree naturalistiche già presenti si ipotizza un perimetro che le contenga trovando, soprattutto a mare, punti di congiunzione tra queste anche in considerazione della previsione di un’area marina protetta dello Stagnone di Marsala individuata dalla normativa nazionale ma mai istituita. Per la parte relativa al litorale la proposta è sostanzialmente simile a quella del riconoscimento MAB UNESCO che è stata avanzata e che ha trovato il consenso dei Comuni di Trapani, Paceco, Misiliscemi e Marsala. Il WWF volutamente non ha voluto quantificare la proposta in termini di ettari sottolineando come il tema non sia quello dell’estensione del parco ma del dare continuità territoriale alle aree naturalistiche esistenti e poco importa se questo, specie a mare, avviene con qualche migliaia di ettari in più o in meno. Opportunità per le attività economiche Secondo il WWF l’istituzione del Parco Nazionale costituisce non solo un’occasione per rendere più omogenea e meglio declinata la tutela di territori su cui già vigono vincoli naturalistici diretti, ma anche un’opportunità anche per le attività economiche. A tale proposito ricorda il “Protocollo sulla gestione della fascia costiera” in applicazione della Convenzione di Barcellona per la tutela del Mar Mediterraneo che per le aree dove la componente marina interagisce con quella terrestre prevede una gestione integrata di tutte le componenti non solo naturalistiche; in particolare tiene conto della fragilità degli ecosistemi e dei paesaggi costieri, della diversità delle attività e degli utilizzi, delle loro interazioni, della vocazione marittima di alcuni di essi. Si tratta quindi di processo di pianificazione e gestione che coordina gli aspetti ambientali, economici, sociali e culturali per garantire lo sviluppo sostenibile delle aree costiere. Approccio partecipato che coinvolga anche la Regione Siciliana Il WWF ritiene pertanto che la legge quadro sulle aree protette, e quindi l’istituzione di un parco nazionale, garantisce questo approccio alla pianificazione in modo partecipato. Nel corso dell’iniziativa sono stati chiariti numerosi passaggi normativi che evidenziano come il dibattito in corso sul parco nazionale sia viziato da numerosi pregiudizi. Norme alla mano è stato illustrato come la Regione Siciliana abbia un ruolo ineludibile sia nell’atto istitutivo e perimetrazione che nella futura approvazione del Piano del Parco, che tale ruolo non può essere espresso eludendo i Comuni che per altro non solo partecipano direttamente al processo di pianificazione del parco ma votano i bilanci preventivi e consuntivi dell’Ente gestore ed hanno diretta competenza sul Piano di Economico Sociale dell’area protetta. Dopo 18 anni dalla norma che prevede il Parco Nazionale delle Isole Egadi e del Litorale Trapanese la richiesta del WWF è forte e chiara: il Ministero dell’Ambiente deve incaricare ISPRA di elaborare una proposta di perimetrazione sulla base anche di dati e conoscenze acquisite dalla Regione. A questo il WWF aggiunge che sarebbe auspicabile cha la Regione ed il Ministero dell’Ambiente promuovessero una campagna di comunicazione sulle opportunità che un Parco rappresenta e realizzassero un processo formativo sui contenuti reali della normativa sulle aree protette per predisporre al meglio il processo partecipativo che verrà avviato. La conferenza di Trapani è stata introdotta dal Delegato Regionale WWF Pietro Ciulla e la proposta di parco è stata illustrata da Gaetano Benedetto, Presidente del Centro Studi WWF. Sono quindi intervenuti i Professori Gioacchino FAZIO (Docente di Scienze Economiche, Aziendali e Statistiche, Università di Palermo), Nicola ROMANA (Docente di Diritto dei Trasporti e del Turismo, Università di Palermo) e Francesco TORRE (Presidente del Consorzio Universitario della Provincia di Trapani). Per le Associazioni Ambientaliste sono intervenuti Giulia Casamento (Responsabile Biodiversità Legambiente Sicilia) e Nino PROVENZA (Coordinatore LIPU per la Sicilia). Mentre la Responsabile della Riserva delle Saline di Trapani e Paceco, Silvana Piacentino, ha portato l’esperienza concreta della gestione di una delle aree individuate come parte del futuro parco nazionale.

items.title: Aperte le iscrizioni agli Stati Generali della Green Economy 2025
items.description: Sono aperte le iscrizioni alla tredicesima edizione degli Stati Generali della Green Economy! La XIV edizione degli Stati Generali della Green Economy
items.body:
Aperte le iscrizioni agli Stati Generali della Green Economy 2025

15 Ottobre 2025

Sono aperte le iscrizioni alla tredicesima edizione degli Stati Generali della Green Economy!La XIV edizione degli Stati Generali della Green Economy, dedicati al tema “Green economy: guidare il futuro in tempi di crisi”, che si svolgeranno il 4 e 5 novembre a Rimini, Ecomondo – Italian Exhibition Group.Durante la Sessione plenaria di apertura il 4 novembre mattina verrà presentata la Relazione sullo stato della Green economy 2025, e la Sessione Plenaria internazionale, The green economy agenda in the new global scenario, che si svolgerà il 5 novembre mattina, approfondirà prospettive, le strategie e policy della green economy all’interno del dibatto globale, da parte dei Governi del mondo del business e della finanza.La quattordicesima edizione degli Stati generali della green economy proporrà una riflessione sulla green economy nel nuovo contesto globale caratterizzato da crescenti difficoltà geopolitiche e da una maggiore competizione anche per l’inasprimento della politica dei dazi attuato dal Presidente Trump. In questo contesto l’Unione Europea, a fronte dei crescenti costi anche economici dei ritardi globali nelle misure di mitigazione e di adattamento climatico, a fronte delle difficoltà e dei maggiori costi dell’approvvigionamento di materie prime, molte delle quali sono ormai critiche, a fronte delle crescenti perdite di capitale naturale e di servizi ecosistemici, dovrebbe, pur con alcuni necessari aggiustamenti, tenere ben ferma, anche per ragioni di sostenibilità e competitività economica, la rotta per l’ineludibile transizione a una green economy, decarbonizzata, circolare e rigenerativa del capitale naturale.

items.title: CIB e Bio 360, rinnovata la Partnership per il 2026
items.description: Anche per il 2026, CIB ha rinnovato la partnership con Bio360, l’Expo delle bioenergie e della bioeconomia. Il Consorzio è fra i “Sector P
items.body:
CIB e Bio 360, rinnovata la Partnership per il 2026

15 Ottobre 2025

Anche per il 2026, CIB ha rinnovato la partnership con Bio360, l’Expo delle bioenergie e della bioeconomia. Il Consorzio è fra i “Sector Partner” dell’evento.
Bio360 Expo si terrà l’11 e 12  febbraio 2026 a Nantes, presso il Parc des Expositions. L’Expo delle bioenergie e della bioeconomia è il punto d’incontro di riferimento per i professionisti internazionali provenienti da contesti multidisciplinari, attira 5.000 partecipanti da 45 Paesi, 450 espositori da più di 25 Paesi e oltre 200 relatori provenienti da tutti i settori della bioenergia, della bioeconomia e della rimozione della CO₂.

items.title: Israele ha già violato i termini dell’accordo con Hamas
items.description: Israele ha dimezzato l’ingresso degli aiuti umanitari e sparato contro civili palestinesi. Accusa Hamas di non consegnare i corpi degli ostaggi morti.
items.body:

Hamas ha liberato tutti gli ostaggi israeliani
		
		
			Hamas ha liberato venti ostaggi israeliani, gli ultimi in vita. Ora secondo gli accordi Israele deve liberare 1.700 prigionieri palestinesi.

La Generazione Z sta guidando le proteste antigovernative in diversi paesi del mondo

Mune, apre a Roma il nuovo museo della Fao su alimentazione e agricoltura

L’India inserisce ingredienti selvatici e cibi locali nelle mense scolastiche per combattere la malnutrizione

items.title: Modern sea-level rise breaks 4,000-year stability in southeastern China
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 15 October 2025

Modern sea-level rise breaks 4,000-year stability in southeastern China
                    Yucheng Lin 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5556-44901,2, Robert E. Kopp 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4016-94281,3, Haixian Xiong4,5, Fiona D. Hibbert 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3686-65146, Zhuo Zheng 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1698-14407, Fengling Yu8, Praveen Kumar 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1766-50601,3, Sönke Dangendorf 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3679-52349, Hailin Yi 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0001-6248-551210 & …Yaze Zhang11 Show authors

Nature

(2025)Cite this article

Subjects
        
            AttributionClimate and Earth system modellingClimate-change impacts

AbstractQuantifying physical mechanisms driving sea-level change—including global mean sea level (GMSL) and regional-to-local components (that is, sea-level budget)—is essential for reliable future projections and effective coastal management1,2. Although previous research has attempted to resolve China’s sea-level budget from the 1950s3,4, these studies capture short timescales and lack the long-term context necessary to fully assess modern sea-level rise in southeastern China5—one of the world’s most densely populated regions with immense socioeconomic importance6. Here we show that GMSL followed three distinct stages from 11,700 years before present (BP) to the modern day: (1) rapid early Holocene rise driven by the deglacial melt of land ice; (2) 4,000 years of stability from around 4200 BP to the mid-nineteenth century when regional processes dominated sea-level change; and (3) accelerating rise from the mid-nineteenth century. Our results arise from spatiotemporal hierarchical modelling of geological sea-level proxies and tide gauge data to produce site-specific sea-level budget estimates with uncertainty quantification. It is extremely likely (P ≥ 0.95) that the GMSL rise rate since 1900 (1.51 ± 0.16 mm year−1, 1σ) has exceeded any century over at least the past four millennia. Moreover, our analysis indicates that at least 94% of rapid modern urban subsidence is attributable to anthropogenic activities, with localized subsidence rates often exceeding GMSL rise. Such concurrent acceleration of global sea-level rise and rapid localized subsidence has not been observed in our Holocene geological record.

                                        Global mean sea level likely higher than present during the holocene

                        Sea-level budget backgroundSea-level change, a direct indicator of climate change, poses substantial risks to coastal communities and will continue to do so in the coming century2. Accurate sea-level projections, which are crucial for managing these risks, necessitate a comprehensive understanding of the various sea-level change mechanisms operating across different spatiotemporal scales7. A typical method for validating our understanding of sea-level change involves comparing the sum of estimates for each physical process with the observed sea-level change, which is often referred to as a sea-level budget study1,8. Because of the limited availability of instrumental sea-level observations, with most satellite and tide gauge data spanning less than 30 and 60 years, respectively, most sea-level budget studies have focused on the twentieth to twenty-first century period1,9. Although these studies effectively explain sea-level budgets post-1900, a period representing a single mode of warming and sea-level rise within a geologically mild baseline, they may not capture the full range of long-term ocean–cryosphere dynamics, highlighting the need to assess recent changes within a broader geological context5.The Holocene, the present interglacial period that began 11,700 years ago, provides a critical framework for evaluating sea-level budgets, as it encompasses several phases of global to local sea-level change10,11. These phases transition from a period of rapid GMSL rise during the early to middle Holocene (10–20 mm year−1, comparable with late twenty-first-century projections2) to a slowdown in the middle Holocene, with rates decreasing to less than 10 mm year−1 (refs. 10,12), followed by stabilization of GMSL during the pre-industrial late Holocene, with rates further declining to mostly  <0.3 mm year−1 (ref. 13). Although geological records provide the only long-term archive of sea-level evolution, their sparse coverage, indirect nature and inherent noise present substantial challenges to reconstructing Holocene sea-level budgets. Consequently, unlike modern sea-level budget assessments that compare the sum of reconstructed budget components (for example, ocean thermosteric expansion and land ice melting) to observed sea-level changes9, geological sea-level budgets often involve statistically decomposing reconstructed sea-level change from geological records13. This method examines various spatiotemporal scales recorded in data related to physical processes, such as long-term tectonic trends that are typically treated as temporally linear over the Holocene, and ocean dynamic signals that vary regionally on decadal to centennial timescales8,11,14.Only a few previous studies have attempted to resolve geological sea-level budgets on the US Atlantic coast and Caribbean8,11,15, leaving long-term sea-level budgets largely unexplored outside North America. The coastline of southeastern China, one of the world’s most densely populated areas with more than 100 million residents, holds immense social and economic importance both domestically and internationally6. Understanding sea-level evolution along China’s coastline is therefore essential for assessing sea-level variability, quantifying human interactions with sea-level change and guiding future coastal infrastructure planning and coastal management7,16.We address this critical research gap through a statistical meta-analysis of global and China geological relative sea level (RSL) proxies, tide gauge data (Fig. 1 and Extended Data Fig. 1) and palaeoenvironmental records (for example, palaeoflood and palaeoshoreline sediments, precipitation proxies) to investigate Holocene sea-level changes in southeastern China. We use a spatiotemporal hierarchical modelling framework, integrating a physics-based glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA) model with Gaussian process (GP) priors to produce site-specific sea-level budget estimates with rigorous uncertainty quantification (see Methods). The reconstructed sea-level budget comprises five components: (1) a GMSL term capturing spatially uniform changes from barystatic signal and global mean thermosteric expansion; (2) a term linked to regional gravitational, rotational and deformational (GRD) effects caused by ice–ocean mass redistribution17; (3) a spatially varying, temporally linear signal capturing slow-changing mechanisms such as tectonics and long-term sedimentary processes18; (4) a regionally varying, temporally nonlinear signal driven by atmosphere/ocean dynamics and tidal range variations8; and (5) a locally varying, temporally nonlinear signal reflecting localized processes (for example, local-scale sediment compaction). More details of our reconstruction approach are described in Methods.Fig. 1: Spatiotemporal distribution of sea-level proxies and cities.a, Spatial distribution of sea-level proxies and main cities along the China coastline, annotated with relevant river systems, provincial boundaries and tectonic plate configurations. This sea-level database was sourced from previous publications22,30,34,51,52,53,54,55,56.Full size imageHolocene sea-level budgetCollected from diverse geological and geomorphological settings, our sea-level database reveals notable spatiotemporal variability driven by several underlying physical processes (Fig. 1). Throughout the Holocene, GMSL rise—driven by continental ice melt from North America, Greenland, Scandinavia and Antarctica—emerged as the dominant driver of sea-level changes in China, as suggested by previous studies12,19,20 (Fig. 2c–h). Constrained exclusively by Chinese sea-level data before 3000 BP (0 BP = 1950 CE, reference year for radiocarbon dating; see Methods), our GMSL reconstruction is presented alongside a recent probabilistic Holocene GMSL estimate in ref. 12, calibrated to a global sea-level database. In the early Holocene (11700–8200 BP), driven by the final termination of North American and Scandinavian ice sheets, GMSL rose rapidly at an average rate of 10.7 ± 3.1 mm year−1 (1σ, applied consistently unless otherwise noted), aligning with the 7.2–12.3 mm year−1 range (68% credible interval, CI) reported ref. 12. By 6000 BP, the demise of the North American Ice Sheet led to a decline in the rate of GMSL rise to 2.8 ± 0.9 mm year−1 (0.3–2.9 mm year−1 in ref. 12), which further decreased to 0.4 ± 0.3 mm year−1 by 3000 BP (−0.3 to 0.7 mm year−1 in ref. 12), primarily because of meltwater from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets10,21. Subsequently, GMSL remained stable until the nineteenth century, a period marked by the onset of the Industrial Revolution and GMSL acceleration (more details in the section ‘Modern sea-level budget’). According to our reconstruction, global mean thermosteric expansion and mountain glacier melt contributed less than 0.2 m to GMSL variation (P ≥ 0.95; see Methods and Extended Data Fig. 2), in agreement with previous process-based reconstructions12.Fig. 2: Spatiotemporal distribution of Holocene China sea level.a, Map showing expected linear-term (l(x, t)) contribution to VLM rate during the Holocene (positive indicates uplift and vice versa). Sea-level budgets are separated into GMSL, GRD, linear, regional nonlinear and local nonlinear components (see Methods). Insets are zoomed-in views since 6000 BP. Previous GMSL reconstructions were compiled from refs. 2,12,19,20,26.Full size imageCompared with Holocene GMSL reconstructions by Creel et al.12 and ICE-6G_C (ref. 19), our estimate indicates substantially lower GMSL during the early to middle Holocene (Fig. 2b). Although these ice models, calibrated to a worldwide sea-level database, align well with most of the North American and European sea-level data15, their RSL predictions are notably higher compared with observations from Asia22, Australia23, Egypt24 and the Arabian-Persian Gulf25 during the early to middle Holocene. By contrast, our reconstruction, which presents a lower GMSL during this period, aligns closely with ice histories proposed by Bradley et al.26 and ANU20, which were calibrated to a regional sea-level dataset from China and Southeast Asia, as well as a global dataset, respectively. However, early Holocene GMSL reconstruction remains an open research question with substantial uncertainties across all approaches, particularly about Antarctic Ice Sheet contributions, which often require extensive field-based ice extent surveys10. Our primary goal here is to provide appropriate boundary conditions for investigating regionally varying signals in China. This is supported by the ability of our model to reproduce independent RSL observations in South Asia and Australia (see Methods), its consistency with ANU20 and Bradley et al.26 and, particularly after 8000 BP, by also overlapping with the uncertainty ranges of Creel et al.12.Beyond the GMSL component, four more sea-level budget components exhibit spatial variability, causing local RSL to deviate substantially from the GMSL curve (Fig. 2c–h). The GRD effects (simulated by the GIA model; see Methods), characterized by land uplift along coastlines and continental interiors and subsidence in offshore areas of China26, are spatially smooth across far-field regions (that is, far away from previous ice sheet margins; Fig. 2c–h). The primary variability arises from the physiography of the continental shelf, which dictates the accommodation space for ocean load intrusion and thereby influences the magnitude of solid Earth deformation. For example, the broad, flat shelf morphology near Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces (Fig. 1) generates a GRD signal in the cities of Taizhou (Zhejiang) and Hangzhou (Zhejiang) that is 3–4 m higher than in Fuzhou and Shenzhen (Fig. 2c–g). By contrast, Sanya, located at the continental shelf margin with limited space for meltwater intrusion, experienced minimal GRD-induced RSL decrease (Fig. 2h).The GRD effects, which include a slow-decaying viscous deformation component (see Methods), contrast with the near-instantaneous response of gravitational and rotational effects to ice sheet melting and theoretically suggests a continuous sea-level fall along China’s coastline during the middle to late Holocene when GMSL reached near the present-day level (the so-called mid-Holocene sea-level highstand26). However, the sea-level database reveals more complex patterns, attributable to vertical land motion (VLM). For instance, no mid-Holocene highstand is recorded in the main deltaic regions such as the Yangtze River Delta (YRD), Pearl River Delta (PRD) and Han River Delta (HRD)22. Furthermore, the timing of the highstand occurs much earlier along the Fujian and Taiwan coastlines, as early as 7500 BP (compared with 4000–6000 BP at Guangdong and Hainan27). These spatial variations reflect the unique geomorphological and geological contexts of each region, shaped by factors governing long-term VLM, including sediment compaction, sediment isostatic adjustment and tectonic activity5,13,18.Our model captures these long-term complexities through a temporally linear and locally varying kernel (see Methods), yielding millennial-average VLM rates during the Holocene that range from uplift at 1.00 ± 0.22 mm year−1 to subsidence at 1.37 ± 0.16 mm year−1 (see Fig. 2a). In depositional environments with substantial sediment input, such as deltaic plains, our reconstructions reveal spatially consistent subsidence signals, with rates of 0.59 ± 0.17 mm year−1 at Taizhou and 0.81 ± 0.17 mm year−1 at Chaozhou (HRD; Fig. 2c,f). Thicker sediment deposition in these regions is generally linked to greater sediment compaction and sediment isostatic adjustment, driving continuous local sea-level rise18. Borehole data from these main deltas indicate Holocene sediment deposition depths ranging from 10 to more than 70 m, with the greatest depths observed near Taizhou, Chaozhou and the offshore PRD22,28,29. These findings align with our long-term subsidence signals, confirming the ability of the model to identify regions in which there is extra subsidence owing to sedimentary processes. In such regions, high subsidence rates can surpass GRD-induced uplift, explaining the observed continuous rising sea-level trend (Fig. 2c,d,f). In megadelta systems such as the YRD, Holocene sediment discharge substantially altered the land–ocean boundary29, a process not captured in our GRD calculation. Although this may cause overestimate in reconstructed subsidence rates by up to  about 0.2 mm year−1, the overall subsidence pattern in the YRD remains robust (see Methods and Extended Data Fig. 3).On the other hand, strong uplift signals are evident along the tectonically active southeastern coastline. This region lies along the active margin of the eastern Eurasian plate, adjacent to the Pacific and Philippine Sea plates. The collision and subduction of the Philippine and Pacific plates towards Taiwan and Fujian have resulted in regional and continuous uplift30 (Fig. 1). The highest uplift rate of 1.00 ± 0.22 mm year−1 can be found near the Fujian coastline, followed by a slightly lower uplift rates of up to 0.67 ± 0.17 mm year−1 and 0.51 ± 0.18 mm year−1 at Guangdong and Hainan, respectively. This overall latitudinal gradient in tectonically induced uplift rates across southeast China agrees well with estimated tectonic uplift rates derived from Marine Isotope Stage 5 marine terraces31. A combined uplift signal caused by tectonic and GRD effects hence explains the abnormally high mid-Holocene sea-level highstand in eastern Fujian (Fig. 2e). This finding is further supported by palaeoenvironmental reconstructions, which reveal that the Fuzhou Basin served as a marine bay environment between 7500 and 7000 BP, characterized by the dominance of brackish and brackish-marine diatoms, indicative of high RSL27,32.Owing to the complex and localized geological and geomorphological conditions along China’s coastline, the linear term captures highly localized patterns. For example, the eastern Fuzhou coastline exhibits a strong uplift signal, whereas the western side shows slight subsidence adjacent to the Fuzhou Basin (Fig. 2a). This subsidence is probably driven by northeast-trending and northwest-trending faults, which have been linked to localized subsidence in the Fuzhou Basin30,33, as well as sedimentary processes driven by 5–40 m Holocene sediment deposition32. Similar variability is observed near the PRD and HRD in Guangdong, in which localized tectonic activity together with sedimentary processes probably explain the rapid transition from uplift to subsidence signals predicted by our model34.Beyond the long-term linear trend, our regional nonlinear term reveals multicentennial-scale RSL fluctuations. The high uncertainty in early to middle Holocene sea-level data, combined with the overlapping influence of several physical processes (for example, tidal range variations, rapid sedimentation changes during fluvial-to-marine transitions and sediment alteration of land–ocean boundary; see Methods), complicates its interpretation for this period. Therefore, our analysis focuses on the past 5,000 years, a period when coastal environments stabilized and tidal ranges approximated present-day conditions29 (see Methods). The most distinctive spatial characteristic of the regional nonlinear term is a dipole-like pattern between eastern China (near the YRD) and southern China (Fujian and Guangdong) across several periods (Fig. 3). For instance, between 4500 and 4400 BP, this term contributed to a sea-level rise of up to 1.02 ± 0.91 mm year−1 near the YRD, while driving a sea-level fall of up to 1.63 ± 0.88 mm year−1 along the Fujian–Guangdong coastline—a similar pattern is also observed between 1500 and 1400 BP (Fig. 3a,c). Conversely, between 2350 and 2250 BP, an opposite pattern emerged, with a sea-level fall of up to 0.37 ± 0.78 mm year−1 near the YRD and a rise of up to 1.84 ± 0.79 mm year−1 in southern regions (Fig. 3b). These centennial-scale sea-level oscillations were also observed by high-resolution coral microatoll-based sea-level reconstructions from the South China Sea, South Asia and Australia during the middle to late Holocene35,36,37.Fig. 3: Regional nonlinear term contribution to spatiotemporal sea-level changes.a, RSL change rate associated with the regional nonlinear term (r(x, t)) between 4500 and 4400 BP (2550–2450 BCE).
